questions.text: 1. An 18-month-old baby presents with weakness of limbs, a cherry red spot on the macula and seizures. The mother has a history of one spontaneous abortion at 4 months. Laboratory investigations showed a deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase. Which of the following biochemical molecules is accumulated in this baby?
questions.solution:
Ganglioside GM2 will be accumulated in this baby.

Ganglioside GM2 accumulates in neuronal lysosomes due to a deficiency in the enzyme hexosaminidase, which converts GM2 into GM3. Diseases associated with the accumulation of GM2 Ganglioside are Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff's disease.

Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disorder due to a deficiency in the enzyme hexosaminidase A. There is an accumulation of GM2 ganglioside. The child presents with a delay in developmental milestones and gradually loses the ability to stand, sit, and vocalise. The onset of dysphagia is earlier than in children with other GM2 gangliosidoses. Other manifestations are early hypotonia developing into progressive spasticity, convulsions, macrocephaly, blindness, deafness, and cherry-red spots in almost all patients. Molecular genetic testing can be done to evaluate for variants in the HEXA or HEXB gene to confirm the diagnosis. Death usually occurs due to aspiration or bronchopneumonia. 

Sandhoff's disease occurs due to a deficiency of the enzymes hexosaminidase A and B. Infants with Sandhoff disease have hepatosplenomegaly, cardiac involvement, and mild bony abnormalities. The juvenile form of this disorder presents as ataxia, dysarthria, and intellectual deterioration, but without visceral enlargement or a macular cherry red spot. The diagnosis of infantile Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease is suspected in an infant with neurologic features and a cherry red spot, and the two can be distinguished based on deficient enzymes.





Other options:

Option B: Galactocerebroside gets accumulated in Krabbe disease due to a defect in the enzyme beta-galactosidase.

Option C: Sphingomyelin gets accumulated in Niemann-Pick disease due to a defect in the enzyme Sphingomyelinase.

Option D: Ganglioside GM1 gets accumulated in generalised gangliosidoses due to a defect in the enzyme beta-galactosidase.

questions.text: 3. A baby presents with low phenylalanine levels. An apparent tyrosine deficiency was seen. But phenylalanine hydroxylase levels were normal. The deficiency of which of the following coenzymes can lead to this manifestation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a baby with low phenylalanine levels and tyrosine deficiency, but normal phenylalanine hydroxylase levels, is suggestive of Biopterin, also known as tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) deficiency.

Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an inborn error of metabolism seen due to a defect in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (classic phenylketonuria) and, less commonly, due to a deficiency of dihydrobiopterin reductase or the enzyme synthesising biopterin (non-classical). These defects result in the impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine.

Examination of cerebrospinal fluid may reveal decreased levels of dopamine and serotonin metabolites. Molecular testing and enzyme assay also help in the diagnosis. Oral supplementation of BH4, control of hyperphenylalaninemia, and supplementation with neurotransmitter precursors are some measures to treat this condition. Sapropterin dihydrochloride is a synthetic form of BH4 and is commercially available, but is expensive.

Other options:

Option A: SAM (S-adenosyl methionine) helps in methyl transfer reactions.

Option B: Tetra hydro folic acid helps in the conversion of serine to glycine.

Option D: Pyridoxal phosphate helps in transamination reactions.

questions.text: 4. A 65-year-old male with a fractured arm presents with bleeding from his gums and perifollicular haemorrhages. His diet mainly consists of tea, biscuits, buns and bread since he stays alone. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this man?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a male with a fractured arm presenting with bleeding from his gums and perifollicular haemorrhages suggests Vitamin C deficiency. Prolyl hydroxylase will be deficient in this man.

Proline is incorporated into the protein and then hydroxylated to hydroxyproline by the enzyme prolyl hydroxylase. The hydroxylation requires molecular oxygen, vitamin C (ascorbic acid), iron and alpha-ketoglutarate. Vitamin C deficiency leads to poor hydroxylation. It is the major biochemical defect in scurvy and also affects the formation of collagen. Amla, guava, lime, and green leafy vegetables are rich sources of Vitamin C, which are not part of this patient's diet, resulting in a vitamin C deficiency.

In vitamin C deficiency, collagen is abnormal, and the intercellular cement substance is brittle. Therefore, capillaries are fragile, with a tendency to bleed even under minor pressure. Wound healing is delayed. In mild deficiency, petechiae can be seen, and in severe cases, haemorrhage may occur in the conjunctiva and retina. Internal bleeding may be seen as hematuria or melena. Gums become painful, swollen and spongy.  

In the bones, the deficiency results in the failure of the osteoblasts to form the intercellular substance, osteoid.  The deposition of bone is arrested without the normal ground substance. This results in weak bones that fracture easily. There can also be haemorrhage into joint cavities. 

Other options:

Option A: ALA synthase requires Vitamin B6.

Option C: Glutathione reductase requires Vitamin B2.

Option D: Galactosyl transferase does not require any specific vitamin.

questions.text: 5. If a frameshift mutation is introduced in a coding gene at the 4th nucleotide of a 900-nucleotide mRNA, what will be the most likely outcome?

choices.text: No change in function due to post-translational modification

questions.solution:
If a frameshift mutation is introduced in a coding gene at the 4th nucleotide of a 900-nucleotide mRNA, there will be a complete loss of protein function. 

A frameshift mutation occurs due to the addition or deletion of bases. Insertions of one or two or non-multiples of three nucleotides into a gene result in an mRNA in which the reading frame is distorted on translation. From the point of insertion onwards, the reading frame of the codons is altered. The reading frame shifts and all the triplet codons thereafter. This leads to a completely different amino acid sequence and can also result in premature stop codon and a non-functional protein.

The corresponding mRNA, when translated, would contain a garbled amino acid sequence. Hence, there is a complete loss of protein function. The deletion of a single nucleotide leads to similar results.

If three nucleotides or a multiple of three nucleotides are deleted from a coding region, translation of the corresponding mRNA will generate a protein that is missing the corresponding number of amino acids. The reading phase will not be disturbed for those codons distal to the deletion because the reading frame is a triplet.

questions.text: 6. A patient presents with anaemia, ataxia and neuropathy and a positive Romberg sign. Lab investigations reveal elevated total homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels. Production of which of the following amino acids could be affected?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with anaemia, ataxia, neuropathy, positive Romberg sign, with lab investigations revealing elevated total homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels, is suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency. Production of Methionine will be affected in this patient.

There are 2 enzymes dependent on vitamin B12:

* Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase

* Methionine synthase

The conversion of Homocysteine to Methionine requires Methionine synthase. A deficiency of vitamin B12 leads to impairment of methionine synthase and also causes accumulation of homocysteine.

Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase catalyses the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA, which is vitamin B12 dependent. When vitamin B12 is deficient, there is an accumulation of methylmalonyl-CoA and urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid (diagnostic test for Vitamin B12 deficiency).



Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause subacute combined degeneration. Patients present with megaloblastic anaemia, ataxia, positive Romberg sign, peripheral neuropathy and positive Babinski sign.

questions.text: 7. A man is stuck in a tunnel for 5 days. He is still alive after 5 days without any food. Which metabolic process is the primary source of energy to his brain?
questions.solution:
The primary source of energy to his brain after 5 days of starvation is Ketosis.

In prolonged starvation (>3 days), acetyl-CoA is converted to ketone bodies to meet the energy needs of the body. Metabolic adaptations during starvation are: 

* The first stage of fasting: The blood glucose level is maintained by hepatic glycogenolysis. The glycogen stores are sufficient for around 18 hours after a meal, following which they begin to deplete.

* The second stage of fasting: Even before the glycogen stores are depleted, gluconeogenesis is accelerated. The amino acids released from muscle are the major substrate for gluconeogenesis.

* The third stage of fasting:

* Lipolysis occurs in the adipose tissue due to the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase, stimulated by an increased glucagon: insulin ratio.

* Free fatty acids are the source of energy in this stage and not glucose. 

* Beta oxidation of fatty acids takes place, which provides acetyl-CoA and subsequently ketone bodies.

* The brain starts utilising ketone bodies from the 3rd day of starvation

* The final stages of fasting: After several weeks of starvation, ketone body synthesis will not take place due to depleted triacylglycerol stores. Excessive production of ketone bodies leads to metabolic acidosis. Metabolic acidosis and dehydration, unless corrected efficiently, will lead to death.

questions.text: 8. A 2-year-old child presents to the OPD with delayed developmental milestones, organomegaly, corneal clouding and weakness. Enzyme assay reveals alpha L-iduronidase deficiency. What of the following compounds will accumulate in this disorder?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with delayed developmental milestones and deficiency of the enzyme L-iduronidase suggests Hurler syndrome. There is an accumulation of Dermatan sulphate and Heparan sulphate. 

Hurler syndrome (Mucopolysaccharidosis I) is a severe, progressive disorder that involves a deficiency in α-L-iduronidase, leading to the accumulation of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate. This results in the clinical manifestations of mental retardation, enlarged head circumference, joint stiffness, short stature, skeletal dysplasia, coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, and cloudy corneas. There may also be a presence of inguinal hernias.

Other manifestations that can be seen are:

* Recurrent upper respiratory tract and ear infections, noisy breathing, and persistent copious nasal discharge

* Valvular heart disease, with incompetence of the mitral and aortic valves, and narrowing of the coronary arteries

* Obstructive airway disease, especially during sleep

* Progressive ventricular enlargement with increased intracranial pressure caused by communicating hydrocephalus also occurs

The earliest radiographic signs are thick ribs and ovoid vertebral bodies. Skeletal abnormalities include enlarged, coarsely trabeculated diaphyses of the long bones with irregular metaphyses and epiphyses. 

The given image below shows coarse facial features, an umbilical hernia, a claw hand, a thoracolumbar kyphosis and broad ribs.



The given image shows cloudy cornea in mucopolysaccharidosis.



Scheie Syndrome is also Mucopolysaccharidosis I. It is characterised by joint stiffness, aortic valve disease, corneal clouding, and mild dysostosis multiplex. Patients have normal intelligence and stature but have significant joint and ocular involvement.

questions.text: 9. A 10-year-old child presents with enlarged orange colored tonsils. There is a history of the death of a family member due to cardiovascular disease. Laboratory investigations show total cholesterol - 80mg/dL, triglycerides - 300mg/dL, and HDL 5mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of enlarged orange colored tonsils with reduced levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) suggest a diagnosis of Tangier's disease.

Tangier's disease is an autosomal dominant condition that occurs due to an absence of ATP-Binding Cassette Transporter-1 (ABC-1), which is involved in transferring cellular cholesterol to HDL. There is a defect in the efflux (flowing out) of cholesterol from cells, and a reduction of HDL and LDL levels in the blood. 

Cholesterol esters get accumulated in tissues. The patient presents with large orange-yellow tonsils, muscle atrophy, recurrent peripheral neuropathies and atherosclerosis.



The table below gives a range of normal parameters.

  Low risk (desirable level) Borderline risk High risk
Total cholesterol (mg/dl) <200 200-400 >240
LDL cholesterol (mg/dl) <130 130-160 >160
HDL cholesterol (mg/dl) >60 35-60 <35
Triglyceride (mg/dl) <150 200-400 >400


Other options:

Option B: Abetalipoproteinemia is a hypolipoproteinemia characterised by the absence of chylomicrons, VLDL, or LDL because of a defect in the loading of apo B with lipid.

Option C: Niemann Pick Disease is an inborn error of metabolism due to the failure of degradation of sphingomyelin. There is a deficiency of the enzyme sphingomyelinase in this condition

Option D: Familial hypercholesterolemia is characterised by defective LDL receptors or a mutation in the ligand region of apo B-100. There is an elevation of LDL levels and hypercholesterolemia, resulting in atherosclerosis and coronary disease.

questions.text: 10. A 10 year old girl presents with freckles on her face, neck, arms and hands. These lesions are sensitive to sunlight. She also has two basal cell carcinomas on her face. Which of the following defect is seen in this girl?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests Xeroderma pigmentosum. A defect in Nucleotide excision repair is seen in this condition.

Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterised by a defective NER (nucleotide excision repair) mechanism. Ultraviolet rays (sunlight) cause the formation of thymine dimers, where covalent bonds are formed between adjacent thymine residues.

There is sensitivity to ultraviolet rays, and exposure to sunlight can lead to blisters on the skin. There are seven XP genes (A to G) necessary for the NER mechanism in humans, and a mutation in any one of them may lead to the condition XP. 

The following image shows an eight-year-old girl with xeroderma pigmentosum. Frontal image of the face, showing large hyperkeratotic lesions with some induration, suspicious of actinic keratosis and early squamous cell carcinoma. Also, numerous hyperpigmented lentigos and xerosis on the entire front of the face. Marked corneal scarring and injection are evident.



Patients with XP have a greater chance of developing skin cancer than do normal persons. Avoiding sunlight and using sunscreen ointment is beneficial. Death usually occurs in the second decade of life due to squamous cell carcinoma of the skin.

questions.text: 11. A man on long-term hydrochlorothiazide presents with cerebellar ataxia, horizontal nystagmus, bilateral symmetric sensory and motor peripheral neuropathy and right heart failure. No history of alcoholism present. Which of the following deficiencies is associated with this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Thiamine deficiency.

Cerebellar ataxia and horizontal nystagmus suggest Wernicke's encephalopathy, while bilateral symmetric sensory motor peripheral neuropathy and right heart failure suggest Beriberi. These suggest Thiamine deficiency. Long-term hydrochlorothiazide administration has also been shown to cause thiamine deficiency.

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency leads to the following conditions:

* Wernicke encephalopathy: It is characterised by ophthalmoplegia, nystagmus, cerebellar ataxia

* Beriberi: It can present with-

*

* Dry beriberi: CNS manifestations like peripheral neuritis with sensory disturbance leading to complete paralysis. Walking becomes difficult. 

* Wet beriberi: Cardiovascular manifestations are prominent. The patient presents with edema of the legs, face, trunk, and serous cavities. Palpitation, breathlessness and distended neck veins are observed. Death occurs due to heart failure

* Korsakoff psychosis

Option A: Selenium deficiency leads to Keshan disease. It is characterised by multifocal myocardial necrosis, cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac enlargement.

Option C: Zinc deficiency leads to poor wound healing, lesions of skin, impaired spermatogenesis, hyperkeratosis, dermatitis and alopecia.

Option D: Deficiency in Vitamin B12 (also known as cobalamin) can lead to megaloblastic anaemia, subacute combined degeneration, and achlorhydria.
